Hi Tony, I believe the issue there is with the definition of a "band":

"=
points that are enclosed by at least two neighbors on opposite sides (e.g. =
left and right) with di=0Bfferent CPPN activation levels"

Note that the po=
ints in the outer black region do not have _two_ neighbors of different lev=
el on opposite sides, so I believe that is the reason they are pruned away.=
  However, it's possible that I'm misunderstanding the question, in which c=
ase please let me know.

Regarding the quote that says, "the CPPN speaks a =
language through its pattern," this idea conveys that of course there is mo=
re than one way to interpret the patterns output by CPPNs for this purpose,=
 and any such method of interpretation is a kind of language.  In other wor=
ds, there might be other perfectly legitimate ways of deciding which connec=
tions to express from an infinite-resolution pattern that are different fro=
m the method in the paper (i.e. those would be different "languages" for th=
e CPPN to express what it wants).  

However, the "language" suggested in t=
he paper is nice in the sense that it allows the CPPN to express one type o=
f connection without being forced to express another at the same time - tha=
t's what the band pruning achieves.  Otherwise you'd get points chosen on b=
oth sides of a sharp border, forcing connections often to be chosen in pair=
s (which seems an undesirable tendency).

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "wilsontg80" <wilsontg@...> wrote:
>
> I am puzzled by the result of band=
 pruning in Figure 3: Example point selection in two dimensions, from Evolv=
ing the Placement and Density of Neurons in the HyperNEAT Substrate.  It se=
ems like the information inherent in the image should include points along =
the black-white edge of the outer black region, but band pruning removes th=
em all.  The figure explains "In effect, the CPPN speaks a language through=
 its pattern that denotes exactly which weights within the hypercube should=
 be expressed."  I am curious why "language" is used here.  
> 
> My goal i=
s to add iterated ES-HyperNEAT to the C++ version at https://github.com/Mis=
terTea/HyperNEAT.  I am presently a hobbyist (my profession is embedded sof=
tware engineering) but considering to someday pursue a PhD involving HyperN=
EAT, etc.
> 
> Thanks,
> Tony Wilson
>
